description: Designed by Sir John Soane as a family home and country residence. Following a three-year conservation project,  Pitzhanger has been returned to Soane’s innovative original design and re-opened to the public in March 2019.

designers.architect: Dance wing: George Dance the Younger

events.name: Free Entry to Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery
events.notes: Advance free tickets should be booked through Pitzhanger Manor and Gallery's website. Please note our normal entry charges will apply on the day this weekend.

events.name: Exterior Building Tour
events.notes: Tours to be booked in advance on Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery's website.  https://www.pitzhanger.org.uk/whatson/open-house-2021-exterior-building-tour/. Please note a ticket to the tour does not include entry into Pitzhanger Manor and Gallery which must be booked seperately. To coincide with the current exhibition, Soane Restored, join this perimeter tour of Sir John Soane’s country manor. The tour will recount how Soane designed the building to be an expression of his own life and work which tells the story of his architectural, artistic and intellectual influences. Revealing the crafts skills involved in the restoration, the tour will explain how the project included a reinstatement of the building’s original layout. Revealing some of the processes of restoration, the tour will look at the re-creation of the decorative elements, such as caryatids, urns and stone roundels, that were derived from classical antiquity.

events.name: BLS Interpreted Exterior Building Tour
events.notes: Please note this tour is specifically aimed at D/deaf audiences who would like to access a tour with BSL Interpretation. https://www.pitzhanger.org.uk/whatson/open-house-2021-bsl-interpreted-exterior-building-tour/. Please note a ticket to the tour does not include entry into Pitzhanger Manor and Gallery which must be booked seperately. To coincide with the current exhibition, Soane Restored, join this perimeter tour of Sir John Soane’s country manor. The tour will recount how Soane designed the building to be an expression of his own life and work which tells the story of his architectural, artistic and intellectual influences. Revealing some of the processes of restoration, the tour will look at the re-creation of the decorative elements, such as caryatids, urns and stone roundels, that were derived from classical antiquity.

events.name: Advance Free Entry to Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery
events.notes: Advance free tickets should be booked through Pitzhanger Manor and Gallery's website. Please note our normal entry charges will apply for those turning up on the day this weekend.

events.name: SEND Family Workshop: Architecture Stories
events.notes: Explore architecture as a family, contribute to a collaborative sculpture and use sound to tell the story of a building. Please note this event is specifically aimed at children with special educational needs accompanied by their parents or carers. Suitable for all ages.

events.name: Sir John Soane’s Birthday Festival
events.notes: All activities are accessible with a free ticket to Pitzhanger Manor and Gallery bookable in advance via our website. Family friendly building tours. A demonstration of the historic paint recreation techniques used for the Chinese Wallpaper room, with the painter involved.  -	Self-guided activities including crafts inspired by the amazing crafts skills used in the restoration, a dressing up box of historic costume and Self-guided tours of the manor and nature trails of Walpole Park.

facilities: Family activities during open house festival

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Pitzhanger Manor was designed by Sir John Soane (1753-1837) one of England's greatest architects. He bought the Pitzhanger site in 1800 in the hope of creating a showcase for his collection and his talents, and a family home for a dynasty of architects, starting with his young sons. In 1810, when his sons proved a disappointment, Soane sold Pitzhanger and moved his library and art collection to his London home in Lincoln’s Inn Fields.

The house stayed in private hands till it was sold in 1901 to Ealing District Council. The building stands in Walpole Park which was formerly the ornamental gardens and parkland to the house, designed for Soane by John Haverfield in 1800.

travel_info: Nearest tube: Ealing Broadway, South Ealing

name: Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery
